## addCollateral and repay share is taken from yieldbox when allowanceBorrow is reduced (instead of userCollateralShare)
This does not seem to be a good idea because
1. allowanceBorrow is deducted in Market. If a user sets allowanceBorrow expecting the user to borrow against there userCollateralShare, the allowed address could instead call addCollateral to take collateral from user yieldbox balance.
1. markets are meant to be isolated, but that isolation breaks cause they can access yieldbox balance of the user.
1. user would still have to set allowance for the market in yieldbox before the transaction could be successful. If user wants the caller to have access to their yieldbox balance, they could instead set that allowance to caller. And caller would take it directly from yieldbox and do whatever they want with it.
So, allowanceBorrow should strictly be used for allowance to userCollateralShare. If `msg.sender` is using allowanceBorrow of `from` address, then `from`'s userCollateralShare should be reduced rather than calling `_addToken`.

### Code snippet
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L282-L290
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L553-L556
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L263-L274
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L732


## liquidatable amount that only ensures solvency puts the protocol at risk
Liquidator can't liquidate more than the `availableBorrowPart` of liquidated user. `availableBorrowPart` is the max liquidatable amount and it calculated in such a way that it ensures the liquidated user is at the solvency/liquidation threshold. This is risky,because the liquidated user would become insolvent immediately collateral worth reduces by a small percentage. Another way this risk could be amplified is lag between real price and oracle price. I'll recommend setting a different threshold for liquidated account. For example if the collaterizationRate is 75%, then liquidated user should have 50% LTV instead of exactly 75%. That way there's enough buffer for market prices to fluctuate before the liquidated user becomes insolvent again.

SGLLiquidation utilizes liquidationBonusAmount but it is not good enough because it is a percentage of `availableBorrowPart`. For example, if `availableBorrowPart` is `5%` of collateral share, collaterizationRate would be `74.5%` which is still too close to `75%`.

### Code snippet
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L790-L799
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/singularity/SGLLiquidation.sol#L225-L242
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/Market.sol#L255-L297


## Liquidators are not motivated to liquidate a user immediately they are insolvent
`callerReward` is a percentage that declines linearly from `maxLiquidatorReward` (default at 10%) to `minLiquidatorReward` (default at 1%) based on `rewardPercentage`. `rewardPercentage` of 0% is the moment a user becomes insolvent and so we want to give liquidator the maximum reward so that they are motivated to liquidate the insolvent user instantly. And indeed the graph looks like this.

![Caller Percentage](data:image/png;base64,)

But the issue is that `callerReward` is the percentage the user would get from `extraShare`. `extraShare` is the difference between `returnedShare` from swap and `borrowShare` that was liquidated. `extraShare` is very likely to increase along with `rewardPercentage`. Although a liquidator gets smaller percentage of `extraShare`, they might be better off because `extraShare` is larger. For example, `10%` of 100 `extraShare` would be 10 shares and that's smaller than `1%` of 5,000 `extraShare` which would be 50 shares.

```solidity
function _extractLiquidationFees(
    uint256 returnedShare,
    uint256 borrowShare,
    uint256 callerReward
) private returns (uint256 feeShare, uint256 callerShare) {
    uint256 extraShare = returnedShare - borrowShare;
    feeShare = (extraShare * protocolFee) / FEE_PRECISION; // x% of profit goes to fee.
    callerShare = (extraShare * callerReward) / FEE_PRECISION; //  y%  of profit goes to caller.

    yieldBox.transfer(address(this), penrose.feeTo(), assetId, feeShare);
    yieldBox.transfer(address(this), msg.sender, assetId, callerShare);
}
```

Therefore, the result is a parabola whereby the liquidators are motivated the liquidate an insolvent user much later and therefore putting the protocol at a greater risk of incurring bad debts.

![Caller share](data:image/png;base64,)

### Code snippet
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/Market.sol#L442-L462
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L576-L626
https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/bigBang/BigBang.sol#L639-L650


## Never use oracle with precision that is less than 5
In [_computeMaxBorrowableAmount](https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/Market.sol#L385-L398) and [_isSolvent](https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-bar-audit/blob/2286f80f928f41c8bc189d0657d74ba83286c668/contracts/markets/Market.sol#L400-425), `EXCHANGE_RATE_PRECISION` is divided by `FEE_PRECISION` before other multiplication. Solidity rounds a number down, so if `EXCHANGE_RATE_PRECISION` is less than `FEE_PRECISION`, the result would be 0 and that would be catastrophic. I'll recommend changing the order of the calculation to avoid such a rounding errror.

```solidity
function _computeMaxBorrowableAmount(
    address user,
    uint256 _exchangeRate
) internal view returns (uint256 collateralAmountInAsset) {
    collateralAmountInAsset =
        yieldBox.toAmount(
            collateralId,
            (userCollateralShare[user] *
                (EXCHANGE_RATE_PRECISION / FEE_PRECISION) *
                collateralizationRate),
            false
        ) /
        _exchangeRate;
}

function _isSolvent(
        address user,
        uint256 _exchangeRate
) internal view returns (bool) {
    // accrue must have already been called!
    uint256 borrowPart = userBorrowPart[user];
    if (borrowPart == 0) return true;
    uint256 collateralShare = userCollateralShare[user];
    if (collateralShare == 0) return false;

    Rebase memory _totalBorrow = totalBorrow;

    return
        yieldBox.toAmount(
            collateralId,
            collateralShare *
                (EXCHANGE_RATE_PRECISION / FEE_PRECISION) *
                collateralizationRate,
            false
        ) >=
        // Moved exchangeRate here instead of dividing the other side to preserve more precision
        (borrowPart * _totalBorrow.elastic * _exchangeRate) /
            _totalBorrow.base;
}
```

## Balancer's pool.getRate is susceptible to read-only reentrancy
`pool.getRate()` of `BalancerStrategy` is susceptible to read-only reentrancy similar to that of Curve's `pool.get_virtual_price`. But this is non critical cause it is used in `BalancerStrategy.withdraw` only and the relationship with output amount is inverse.

https://github.com/Tapioca-DAO/tapioca-yieldbox-strategies-audit/blob/05ba7108a83c66dada98bc5bc75cf18004f2a49b/contracts/balancer/BalancerStrategy.sol#L200-L203

```solidity
uint256 pricePerShare = pool.getRate();
uint256 decimals = IStrictERC20(address(pool)).decimals();
uint256 toWithdraw = (((amount - queued) * (10 ** decimals)) /
    pricePerShare);
```
